comment: Very smooth considering the proof. The flavor has quite a bit of complexity, definitely worth purchasing, it’s very enjoyable.
tasted at Evan Williams speakeasy. very smooth
Wow! Vanilla nose through finish. Taste is full with great finish. Can not believe this proof is this high given how smooth it is.
So much flavor on the palate, fantastic nose. Grab a bottle while you can, these go quick.
Complex earthy taste. lots of apple notes, caramel, a little oak. smooth up front and a long lasting medium hot finish
Explosion of flavors. Vanilla caramel. Could be best bourbon for me

Nose- Cinnamon sugar
Body- Cinnamon continues with a bit of apple
Finish- Black pepper becomes increasingly prevalent

Very similar to the William Heaven. I think I like this one better.

HAZMAT, 140.2 proof. Nose is CRAZILY... muted? I was expecting a mack truck but it's pleasant. Caramel, cola, oak and spice. Some musk as well. On the palate, so mellow and smooth. Not true. It's hot, spicy, and numbing, but also sweet and velvety. Some cacao nibs, some nuts, some cola. Fantastic. 8/24/18
Incredibly smooth for a 130+ proof bourbon.  Very sweet but in a savory delicious way.  A great buy at any price point under $100.

Reviewing Batch B517. Whiskey of the Year on Whiskey Advocate's top 20 of 2017.
This one clock's in at 124.2 Proof, which is the lowest proof yet to be released. As with all batches this one is age stated at 12 yrs.
Upon entry you are hit with a big caramel and burnt brown sugar note. Moving to the mid pallette leads to some tobacco, orange peel and oak. Finish is long with tobacco, pepper and more oak. Everything is wonderfully in balance. Adding 4 drops of water tames the oak and pepper notes and brings out some vanilla and Graham cracker notes. It's wonderful neat or with some water. 
This one lives up to the hype. Instant buy and definitely better than the A117. I have an unopened C917 that I hear is also great. The consistency of these batches is truly remarkable.
Wow! Great aroma and sweet initial taste. Then hot, hot, hot, cinnamon burn through to the finish. Great finish lingering slow burn. Batch B518 at 133.4 proof.
Not super alcoholic on the nose, warm in the mouth, intense flavor,m
@thekeep - when walking like a ginger is the only option #foreignobjects
Is whiskey considered a foreign object?

Hella good. Caramel and vanilla on the nose, sweet and citrusy, black pepper on the finish. Adding two drops of water opened up to butterscotch aroma and sweet apple taste, and it coats your entire mouth with a caramel aftertaste

A118; 4.5/5.0
    
Nose: 4 | caramel, vanilla, fruit and wood
Palate: 4.5 | really great mouthfeel, sweet, rich caramel, vanilla and oak
Finish: 4 | big hug that hangs with you; spice and woodiness on the finish 
Price: 4
    
Verdict: Bottle
Awesome...

Batch B518. 133.4 proof.
Nice. Would like to try against B107 and the C batches. 4.23.

B518
133.4 proof
66.7%

Smooth and warm on the tongue. Very nice.

A drop of water opened this up to add a little heat.
Smells of apples and cinnamon. Delicious flavorful
Strong, according to Dustin I am a Communist for not giving this 5 stars.

A winner! The burn is sooo good. This one packs a punch with a rich/complex depth of flavors that will not disappoint. If asked to describe this in one word, I would say in all caps: BOURBON! You''ll understand once you try it.
Complex delicious flavors. Good with one ice cube
Powerful. Smacks you in the face. Great nose.

Without a doubt the finest bourbon I’ve ever had the pleasure of tasting. Fell in love with the A118 batch and just picked up a bottle of the B518. Sells in New Hampshire for $49.99 which for a 12 year old, unfiltered, barrel proof whiskey is an absolute steal. You literally can’t do better than that. Cheers to Heaven Hill which is rapidly becoming my distillery of choice.

At the price, this is very good. It's what I would reach for when a "good stiff drink" is needed. But Bourbons like this I would generally not drink too much of at any one time. Maybe a finger or two...okay, two! I do the same with 3 various Booker's Batches, all very high ABV. The finish will continue to dry your tongue like it's been left out in the Sun at the beach. Drinking it neat, I get two distinct spice burns at different times, one well after the swallow. Definitely agree with @PBMichiganWolverine about the water/ice. That tames this beast and allows for a different experience. Not saying which is the better. Just depends on the mood.

The strength, the burn, the sweet without saccharine, in short, the wonderful bourbon-ness of these liquors allows me to enjoy them without needing too much and also allows me to nurse these suckers 'til the cows come home. 
    
    Thanks to the many posters on this whiskey, especially @PBMichiganWolverine  for stimulating my curiosity about it.
    
    $64.99 USD in PA
Sharp front, slight kick at the end, not sweet, not harsh, hot

I had a pour of their latest release, B518, during a one day quick Chicago business trip.  This is the 12 yr old, taken to cask strength full flavor.  Each batch varies, but they’re all supposedly good to amazing.  I’ve had previously two other EC barrel proof releases, one courtesy of @Dreaming-of-Islay, the other from a bottle I bought.  Both excellent.  But this beats those two.  Hands down this has now taken the top spot for my favorite bourbon, which was previously held by the 2016 Four Roses LESB.  At a mere $60-80, to me this is a no-brainer buy, rather than chasing the Four Roses LESBs, or the BTACs.  This is inches away from being a hazmat warning, clocking at nearly 135ABV.  You get the firepower, but surprisingly none of the heat and burn.  It’s all buttercream and vanilla frosting.  It’s thick and creamy...almost like they put in full fat cream into the vatting.  Only once I made the claim of “you gotta buy this”, and that was for the Brora 30yr old, specifically targeted to the whisky connoisseur ...but this at $69.99 is a must buy for the general masses that love bourbon.  (the price I paid.  As soon as I finished my pour, I bought it immediately online).

B518 is the best whiskey I have ever tasted. Amazing stuff. Even at 133 proof, little to no burn. 
Deep Amber. Nose for days.
So smooth for something so strong. You can really taste the barrel

Aroma: Stone fruit, floral, oak, & hay.
Flavor: Cherry jolly rancher, cinnamon, charred oak, hernal, & floral.
Warm vanilla, honey, cocoa tea, & hay.
Aftertaste: Spiced honey, orange zest.
Body: Heavy, syrupy, & round

Each aspect of this bourbon is loud. You can smell it from across the room, and each sip shares something new. Heavy, boozy, and delicious it immediately hits the palate like candy before opening up. It is powerfully balanced with exceptionally pleasant complexity even at 136proof. A surprising steal at the price for what is now in my top 5.
Batch b518 delicious with a ridiculously long finish

Tasting the C917 Batch. 
This was the final release of 2017. It clock's in at a healthy 131 proof. As with all batches it's age stated at 12 years. This was the highest proof release of 2017.
I really enjoyed the previous 2 2017 releases and have been excited to give this one a try. I have been sitting on this bottle for a while and finally decided to cork it!
Upon entry you are hit with a big toffee, vanilla and honey notes. As we roll to the mid pallette you are hit with very big spice notes of cinnamon and clove. They are a little overpowering. As they finally recede, the oak presence and vanilla cap the meduim finish. Adding a splash of water made a big difference. The spice recedes and this Bourbon really opens up. The spice is replaced with rich burnt brown sugar and cigar box notes. This is one of the few ECBP releases I would recommend adding water too. Due to this I would give it a 4/5 vs a 5/5. However, with the water added it's outstanding. The whole 2017 vertical is fantastic!
I’m trying the B517 neat and it’s excellent. Full of flavor.

C918
This particular batch was nothing short of great!  I had a friend who picked up this bottle on the way to a coastal fishing trip.  I have A118 in my personal vault unopened.  It is too hot without water.  once you get the proof right...Man!  Vanilla and baking spices dominate.  Cinnamon and clove spice.  A warm Kentucky hug with a long satisfying finish.  IMO...a must have for the barrel proof collection.

Tasting: B518 from glen cairn glass both neat and then with cap of water.

Appearance:  Amber and slightly oily, plenty of legs and reddish hue.

Nose: (5.0)  Very nose forward bourbon.  Notes of oak, butterscotch, toffee, vanilla with spice.  Ethanol hardly noticed as compared to proof.

Palate: (4.5) toffee, carmel, leather and more oak/ barrel taste, dark fruit and red apple in the background.  Very rich with thicker mouth feel.  A bit oily but pleasing.  Spice comes in at the end with alot of heat.  Adding water brought out more fruit and syrup, kind of like a cherry jolly rancher.  More complex with water added.  Really opens up a new level and cools the burn.

Finish (4.5):  Long lasting with spice, oak barrel and more toffee.

This is a great barrel proof.  You could sit for an hour and discuss the flavors that play well with each other.  The nose however is the star.
Not as hot as the proof. Worth every penny

Whew, powerful stuff. Really full and rich, a little sweet with some heat. I like it. A lot.

B-518
Varies so much between batches but it seems to keep getting better. Splash of water or a small cube and some time will really open this up.

(edit November 12 - I increased my score on this to 4.50 from 4.25.  I just keep coming back to this one, liking it more each time)

Neat, Room temperature, no water added in subsequent tastes, from a Glencairn.  Batch B517.
 
The nose will wake you right up and demand attention.  Complex.  I get vanilla and rye.  A little oak.

The palate is warm and lively.  Cinnamon is notable.  I'm still getting vanilla too.  Subtle sense of sweetness also.

The finish is gorgeous.  Flavors stay with you and mellow into a warm coating that lasts and lasts.  Spicy... Still feeling the cinnamon tingle.
Pure, rich bourbon!  Great flavor and deep, rich finish!

Tasting:  Neat in glen cairn and then 3 drops of water in 1 oz. pour.  Batch B518

Nose: (5.0)  A bit of oaky, musty barrel and then the mother load of caramel and butterscotch comes through.  Fills the room with deliciousness

Palate: (5.0)  I got heathbar and a bit of ethanol. Scrumptious chocolate and butterscotch are the main players.  The vanilla plays in the background and then the heat builds and hits you upside the head.

Finish: (5.0) Long finish with spice and cinnamon, beautiful caramel aftertaste.  Coats the palate and builds to a comfortable inner warmth.

This bourbon is spectacular good.  It is one of the few bourbons of which if I could only have one on a disserted island it would be it.
Rocket fuel! Wafting it burns the nose, but sooo smooth!

Robust flavor  powerful heat and sweet. Dominant cinnamon cherries caramel chocolate on the initial palate.
On the nose heavy wood and vanilla. 
The finish is a serious burn of cherries and toffee.

Smooth for such high proof.  B518.
Caramel and toffee and toasted oak

The aroma is intoxicating! Sweet cotton candy and vanilla. The flavor is just as inspiring! Smoke upfront quickly fading into a semi sweet plumb and then ending into a long spice leather burn. Excellent!!!
B517 - Tons of oak on the nose, some cocoa. Caramel, medium spice. Not as hot as I expected for 124proof. Glorious. Wish I had a few backup bottles.

Batch B518. First pour out of a bottle straight from HH gift shop. Deep amber color. Nose is almost all ethanol right out of the gate, revealing vanilla after a bit of breathing. Viscous mouthfeel. Charred oak and creamy vanilla forward, followed by a wave of cinnamon and a very long slow burn finish. Fantastic bourbon. Grab a bottle if you can, and share with friends & family.
heavy cinnamon and caramel sweetness, some burn up front and at finish due to proof, long and pleasant finish with toffee note, very tasty bourbon

Not a fan of EC, but BP I am. Had the A release of ‘18, would buy under $55 or so. Cinnamon, graham cracker. Really opened up as it sat. Have to let it open up though, otherwise it’ll eat your face off.

This is how bourbon should be made. Legs are pretty thick. The nose really draws you in and arouses the curiosity with heavy caramel and and some oak. The nose tells you up-front how great the taste is going to be, and when the taste comes on, it doesn't let you down a single bit.

It has a full body, hits solid at the front of the palate. The flavors are strong, but not overpowering. Amazingly, at 133 proof, it finishes rather kindly; like a bro-hug. It's complex, and the flavors of caramel, oak, honey, and a sort of clove-like rye spice copulate like a foursome on your palate - not ending with a particular spike of anything, but like a climax with a mild grunt from the masculine flavors and "oohs" and "ahhs" of the feminine flavors. It's literally like that. You could sit in a recliner, wearing a red smoking jacket, sipping a glass of this stuff, as the lingering moans of a couple of exhausted broads echo through your marble-clad chamber... Like you just floored the whole crowd with your violin solo, stole the gaze of all the women, and walked out of the concerto hall as the orchestra humbly fades out with your shadow... Like your boss calls you in to tell you that you got the promotion, but you tell him "I appreciate that Bob, but I just came by to tell you that I'll be VP of Communications at XXX Co. starting Monday. By the way, I can recommend you a good secretary because Brenda will be joining my team as soon as my plaque is ready." This is the quintessential bourbon as far as I'm concerned.

Batch B518
Honey, vanilla, cinnamon and some oak on the palate. Alcohol burn in the mouth, but not as much as I expected for such high proof, leading to a gentle warmth going down.

A117. Haven't had this batch in a while, and it holds up. On the nose, classic bourbon notes, with caramel, sandalwood, oak, brown sugar, and a bit of... soap? Surprisingly no sting on the nose given the proof. Smoothness carries over to the palate (relative to the proof, mind you). The spice and heat are still there, and a sharp acidic note. It's sweet, the floral note from the nose carries over as well. Some leather. Pecan nibs and barrel char at the end. The 2017 batches are very good, this may be my favorite of the three. 11/15/18
Puts you in a different head space. Whole lotta fire here.
Very intense but also alcoholic neat. With water, you get that full-bodied richness and sweetness and a hint of bitterness on the palate. 92

This is a pretty amazing bourbon - a different taste in every sip or smell. Sometimes you get a wallop of oak, sometimes it’s more of a heath bar/toffee kind of thing, and every once in a while there’s even a bit of brine. Just an extremely complex but also very drinkable bourbon. (This review based on the B518 batch.)

Fairly oily, and clings to the glass. Dark amber color. 

Oak, nuts, leather, and caramel nose. 

This is the epitome of the Kentucky hug. There’s immediate warmth that is pleasant and calming. This feeling is by far my favorite thing about this bourbon. 

The flavor is leathery, and the rye shines through deliciously, with dark chocolate and coffee notes. 

The finish is extraordinary oaky, a bit of brine, and lingers, fading into a roasted grain flavor. It’s a long finish. This will forever be a favorite.

After reading such high reviews of this I lucked out and stumbled across a bottle at my local ABC store, which almost never gets any of this. The bottle I purchased was batch C918 and it’ s a little over 131 proof. I payed $60 USD.

Damn. This is a very good bourbon. VERY good.  The nose is sweet - I get vanilla, sweet corn, baking spices, cake frosting, and oak. Maybe a little molasses. The alcohol is definitely there but not overpowering like I was expecting. That being said, it’s 131 proof so don’t go nose diving unless you need to trim back some nose hairs. Being a 12 year bourbon, the oak was not too heavy, but rounded out the nose perfectly.
The taste. Oh, the taste. It mirrors the palate perfectly. I tried it neat first, which seems suicidal at 131 proof but my goodness how can a 131 proof bourbon be so smooth? Perfect for a cold winter night, the warmth overtakes you like a cozy blanket in front of a nice crackling fire. Perfect. I then added a small piece of ice. The gradual melting of the ice peels back layer after layer of flavor. What a dram. I’m going to savor this bottle for a long time. 

If you came a cross a bottle, buy it. I’m not one to pay $60 on a bourbon I haven’t tried, and I honestly can’t justify it in many cases. This was a splurge. And it was one of the best bourbon purchases I have made. At $60, it is a steal. I have never tried the other ECBP batches so have nothing to compare to but it’s better than any bourbon I have enjoyed.

Addendum: Just bought a bottle of A119. It's a blazing 135 proof. The heat on this one is a lot less friendly than C918. The palate is still excellent but not as complex as C918. I'd still rate this one a 4.25/5. Perhaps with a little time the heat will be more tame.
Drinking A117 at 127 proof.   One of my favorites
Caramel, comes in hot goes down smooth like butterscotch
Wow. So intense! Cinnamon and graham cracker. Long-lasting spice
Really good.  Lots of flavor.  Can buy in Lander off the shelf for 60ish.  One of my faves so far.
Ethanol nose. Caramel on the tongue with good burn. Finish is nice.
Really solid. Strong cinnamon and vanilla. Smoky and leather on the back. Allspice aftertaste. 130 proof makes you warm and fuzzy.
ECBP #3; 66.6%. Lots of oak and pepper. Astringent. Lots of dark fruit notes. Finished it in a Manhattan. Worked great in the cocktail.
Nose changed, capturing some sweetness now an oak.  Bring the heat!  High alcohol, feel it in my throat.  Lots of oak
Nose is very strong smelling the pepper, char, and oak. Very spicy from start to finish! Strong bold flavor.
B517 ... 124.2 Proof / 62.1% Alcohol .. Tons of flavor. Good amount of heat and burn. Too much for me at the moment. 3/5 for now as my pallet grows in this game of Bourbon.

Nose: very low alcohol, oak, fruit, citrus, sweet

Taste: alcohol taste, oak, leather, fruit, peppery

Finish: oak, leather
Very good and strong flavor. Great to mix with. Need to water down if straight. Great with eggnog
Hits slowly but sweet and fiery when it does. Above average finish.

Great nose 
Full and thorough finish
Still smooth for barrel proof
Whiskey Club - Doug’s house
So smooth for a barrell proof! Notes of black cherry, leather and more subtle fruit. Wonderful finish.
Barrel makes it strong, but flavors still come through.
Wow. What an awesome bourbon. Mine is batch A119 at 135.2 proof. Very complex and smooth for such a high abv.

The nose of batch B517 immediately hits you with oak, rye spiciness, leather, soft pepper and a hint of chocolate, which all softens as it breathes. The palate is dry with oak upfront along side pepper and rye, followed by toasted vanilla, and a hint of caramel and mint. The finish is long, dry and spicy with oak, rye, pepper and fading vanilla. Not a complicated whiskey but it is excellent in what it brings to the table.
Nose is powerful, bits of cream, honey, caramel sweetness. The taste starts out with dried fruit sweetness and quickly transforms into a “red hots” candy with a long, sustained finish

Nose: vanilla, caramel and alcohol. Immediate cinnamon and burn. Surprisingly smooth for 135 proof. Burn lingers slightly while it warms the chest. Opens up with bright citrus fruit flavors. Absolutely delicious.
Dump b. Great nose. Pretty smooth for such a high abv.

"Batch C918. 131 proof with strong alcohol nose. Even after airing it for 15 minutes still couldn’t get anything, which is disappointing. Taste was hot yet smooth. With water added it is very nice. Nice “thick” bourbon with slight sweetness and certainly rye heat. Hoping now that it’s been opened I’ll get some better nose. Great tasting stuff otherwise.
Big beefy BBQ nose. Spicy pallet, rich and oily. Spiciness lingers on your tongue. Slight taste of coffee on the finish. Follow with a sip of water. Superior. Currently, my favorite.
Def taste the proof, bit too much astringency. nice caramel and maple notes
Wow.  Potent rye pop with that.

Tasted several batches last night. B918 is a masterpiece - which is why this is getting 5 stars for me. It is everything I want in bourbon - big, bold, vanilla, caramel, and plenty of oak. This hits in all the right places. That being said I have had other versions that aren't the quality of this one.
B518: Great with one ice cube.

Batch C917. 65.5%.

I'd heard the hype for quite some time, so I decided to finally take the plunge and shell out for this one. This will be the first of a short string of bourbon reviews, and I've got to say this one is my favorite by a decent amount (also by far the most expensive).

I often read comments where reviewers suggest that a particular whiskey is almost there, and that a cask strength release would put it over the top. Heaven Hill ensures that one will never say such a thing about Elijah Craig, with this Barrel Proof taking what is a pretty decent entry level bourbon and bringing it to its full potential.

Nose: The makes itself known immediately. Caramel, vanilla, crisp red apple, cinnamon, black pepper, and a heavy oak presence. Also a big leather note, like a baseball glove. Very nice start.

Palate: The oak is presence is even more prominent than it was on the nose. Nice barrel char. Caramel, vanilla, and cola are the most prominent. Nutmeg, brown sugar, and cocoa are also there. It's mostly sweet, but there is some black pepper and cinnamon spice. Done to perfection, and astoundingly drinkable without water at 131 proof.

Finish: Long finish that comes in waves. Not all that hot. I'll call it a warming finish. Definitely cinnamon and black pepper, but there are sweeter chocolate and cola. Amazing from start to finish.

This is my first batch of ECBP, and now I'm going to be hunting down as many as I can possibly find. It's an absolutely phenomenal experience. At $90, it's an expensive buy, but worth every penny. I think that the standard EC is a respectable entry level bourbon. But at Barrel Proof, this stuff really shines. Well done on top shelf pour, Heaven Hill.

This is batch C918 from 2018

Proof: 131

Nose: toasted nuts, cranberries and assorted dark fruits, toffee, leather

Palate: very rich and it hits quite sweet at first then the rye kicks in with cinnamon and slight vanilla spices 

Finish: sweet at first again but quickly dry and warm, just enough bite

Tasted this side by side with a 14-year Knob Creek Single Barrel and the Elijah Craig wins in complexity and balance. 

The proof is up there but the alcohol is well hidden by a cornucopia of flavors.

Batch C917 - After multiple bottles of this, it can have a range of taste depending on the amount of time/air the bottle has gotten. Can range from burn your entire digestive tract, to a hot oily brown sugar dark fruit with alcohol burn gem, to a full on brown sugar butterscotch smooth slick oily treat. At any stage, this is one of my favorites. Its uniqueness and consistency of quality are what keep this on the shelf at all time, no matter how hot this can get.
B517. YES!! Gloves of leather lap my cheeks and rye fruits come mingle with some tree ents who gave their lives for the barrel. Yum :)

batch B518, 66.7% abv
tasted side by side with small batch...
the barrel proof is:
nose- less nutty, less tannin, less banana more vanilla and sweeter. turns to a nutty/ chocolate bitterness while you sip.
palette- strong dried cherry and apricot, salt...

first barrel proof in a while... need to remind myself to take smaller sips. lol.

add a couple drops of water...
brings the bitterness out in the nose and nuttiness similar to the small batch. it's quite nice near halfway between the two, possibly 55%.  this brings it near the small batch flavor profile but more intense.
Very good on the rocks or opened up

The deep caramel color sets the stage for this flavor bomb. A rich bourbon aroma punctuated with citrus and syrup. Sweet and chewy taste with oak that continues through the finish of peppery orange goodness.

You simply will not find a rich delicious bottle like this for this price. This is an insanely strong thick rich mature bourbon. The flavors, well, its what you can detect but this bottle will satisfy the GTS and WLW lovers out there. You like the old thick 130 proof BTAC bottles? Well here is a great alternative. In fact. I am not sure if i rank this bottle or GTS higher. Need more tasting... :)
Spicy hot and sweet it’s got a lot of burn to it but is rather nice. Wouldn’t buy it again just not my thing.

lots of alcohol heat, which is to be expected at barrel proof, but moreso than others at this ABV; still delicious - lots of good flavor surrounds that burn; will try with a few drops of water next time
Thick and flavorful with caramels, burnt sugars, vanilla and oak. I have enjoyed every sip.

Batch: C918
Age: 12
Year: 2018
Proof: 131

Nose: toffee, biscuits, candied nuts 

Palate: rich with hints of baking spices, and vanilla

Finish: very smooth for the high proof. Probably the smoothest bourbon above 125 I’ve ever had. The only bite comes from the proof level and definitely not the recipe; this is a 10% rye mashbill. Slightly bitter at the end. 

Overall excellent.

Gigantic, heavy hitting and slow burn is the name of the game here.  

The nose is actually surprisingly fruity, floral and light, deceptive for what comes next. The is a bit of a heavy pepper and oak undertone that betrays, the flavors though.

The palette is full of leather, oak, vanilla and banana. Incredibly thick, like a less potent version of GTS (but better?)

Finished with a long slow burn and a pepper kick in the nose.
Very smooth and balanced.  Great hints of vanilla, and cherry with a nice heat that appropriately lingers to make delicious.

Nose: vanilla, cherry, maybe some rye but I’m coming off midwinter night’s dram so that could be in my head
Taste: can definitely feel the proof, I’m still getting the rye, the vanilla and cherry from the nose is there with cherry almost cough syrupy
Finish: my tongue is begging for mercy
After reading reviews: I guess the rye wasn’t just me, my tongue is so spent I’m not sure on the viscosity.  I actually think this might be 12 year barrel proof based on the flaviar pictures.  I left out oak, but yeah oak in the face.
amazing, bold, finishes well rounded with a pungent oaky nose.

A good smelling nose. Can’t pick up ima trying specific. Have had a few as of this writing. Will update after this writing to see if I found something different as the first. Right now it does smell sweet very strong of corn. On to the pallet let me give it a go... in my state I believe it is a sweet and very tasty has a slight burn. Leaves the pallet with an overall good flavor to linger on. The burn is still there but very subtle a very enjoyable feeling. Would recommend this pour to anyone. Like I have said before I will update as a first pour.

0-1: Beyond bad. Complete waste of money according to my tastebuds. 
2: Bad. Simply not my taste
2.5: Sub-par. Ill drink it... but only because its whiskey.
3: Good. Decent stuff, but not a rebuy
3.5: Very good. I might buy again
4: Excellent: Will be purchasing a bottle asap
4.5: Incredible: top of the purchase list
5:Amazing: cost and taste are worth every cent"

Nose: lots of oak, leather, ground coffee, toffee, dark chocolate, with fainter hints of vanilla, pepper, and caramel.

Palate: caramel and butterscotch upfront that gives way to candied fruit, leather, pepper, and baking spice. Drinks below proof (134 in my case) but you can still tell it’s a barrel proof bourbon. It has just the right amount of heat. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. 

Finish: One of the longest I’ve ever had in a bourbon. The flavors linger for minutes. All the sweet flavors fade and give way to leather, oak, and dark chocolate.

Overall: EXCELLENT. This is an excellent value at its MSRP of $60 and the best barrel proof bourbon I’ve had to date. I’d bet that it’s the best barrel proof bourbon you can find relatively easily. Drinking this makes me forget about the loss of the standard 12 year Elijah Craig and the fact that it’s double the price of its NAS small batch brother. This could probably benefit from a few drops of water, but it’s also fantastic neat. The oaky finish pairs well with the sweet flavors on the palate, and the heat is very manageable despite the potent proof.
Wonderful nose... All the barrel, molasses, honey, and some underlying corn aromas. Taste is amazing. Very warming, complex, and classic.
This bourbon is exceptional. Definitely one to be savored
Big, rich, complex taste with a long finish. Hearty bourbon, but doesn’t taste as strong as 135 proof. Really good with a few drops of water.

Love love love this. Rich caramel, toasted brown sugar, sweet fruit pie immediately on the palette. Surprisingly little heat for this proof. Complex mix of flavors follows the upfront sweetness, including cinnamon, vanilla, and more.

Nose: caramel, sugar, vanilla, dark cherry, molasses, marshmallow, hint of something floral and oak with late fruit

Body: smooth and full but not boozy as the proof would suggest

Palate: spicy, caramel, vanilla

Finish: long hot, sugary and spicy

Note: I’m not sure what anise is but I think I smell and taste it (😂) this is such a delicious bourbon hot and spicy and sweet with loads of flavor... my style. Eeeeeee-lie-jaaaaaaaaah!
C917 131 proof. One of the finest whiskey's I've ever tasted
Strong.  Smooth for a barrel proof.  Got this through trade on secondary.
Great but very strong, if you like a strong kick this is excellent
Great!  I love this, and at $59 it is heaven (too bad it is hardly ever in stock).  Smooth like the regular with  a huge boost of rich flavor, a little cocoa dry finish.  Yummy stuff
Some B517 to celebrate the Spartans win over Duke. Bring on the Final Four!

opened it up with a bit of filtered water.
nose:
hot, cereal grain toasted hazlenut and light roast coffee, warm spices
spicy, cinnamon and clove front, toasted oaky finish, new baseball bat.  virtually no sweetness



this just isn't my favorite type of bourbon.

Whisk(e)y: Eljiah Craig Barrl Proof – C917

Nose:

The rye and 65.5% abv gives the nose a peppery sensation along with a flare of the nostril. When you go deeper there’s a memorable smell of leather and cinnamon sticks. Roasted nuts also shows up when you give a nose side to side. You can tell that the nose on this is more complex than the Elijah Craig Small Batch. 

Palate:

After letting this dram sit for 20 minutes neat, here is my take. The first sip coats  your entire mouth. You can definitely feel the layers and complexity on the inner cheek. Very smooth. Heat on the back of the tongue and stays present slightly a minute or so afterwards. Great spice and manageable at 65.5% abv. Keep in mind, this is straight from the barrel and not meant for the kiddies or anyone over the age of 70.

Sip number two I could pick up dark brown sugar / molasses. It has more weight to it than your regular whisk(e)y. I’ve read that chocolate is present in this whisky which I would have to agree to a degree. I find it difficult to pick out, but can sense a subtleness of it if my senses are correct.

Overall: 

This is a great whisky. Plain and simple. I feel that any range of connoisseur would like this, yet, collectors and reviewers will appreciate quite a bit. I love high abv’s personally and find that with such a high percentage on the bottle, it still packs a lot of flavour. Elijah Craig scores major points in this category as the rule of thumb is the higher the abv the less flavour. I sip this only on special occasions or in this instance for reviews. It’s not a whisky to be chugged down, but more so a keeper for the holidays or special occasion. Is this worth buying? Hell ya! Stock your shelves with this one. 
Cheers,
Fantastic. Suuuuper rich nose. the taste is honestly not quite as oily as nose leads but the taste is huge. Spice, Vanilla, bit of cocoa.  "NAS"? It literally says aged 12 years.
This is good. Nice heat. Finish that lasts a week. Nice initial caramel sweetness.  Score a bottle if you can find it.
This is a absolutely awesome bourbon. Smooth as silk for a barrel proof. Lots of sweet chocolate , barrel wood and toffee. The price is great for the quality of this dram!
Tried this next to blantons loved the boldness of the juice. Really tasty and rich flavor.
Nose of ethanol, palette of caramel and hard candy, great finish burn.....surprisingly smooth with the proof
Çok unique bir tadı var, biraz su katılmalı
Very vanilla nose, almost sugary on the tongue, though the proof has a real burn. Mostly burn in the finish.

C918 65.7%

Nose: rich and sweet. Very classic bourbon notes. Dusty corn, candied cherries, vanilla extract, boot leather, cedar, cola syrup, sawn oak boards, cinnamon and all spice, baked apple pie, molasses cookies, lightly roasted coffee beans, black tea and honey, grape candy, 

Palate: thick and oily, coats the mouth. hot ethanol burn on the tongue and going down, cherry cough syrup, brown sugar,  cherry cola, eucalyptus, mint, marzipan, chocolate covered cherries, orange marmalade, root beer. 

Finish: drying and slightly tannic yet the oils linger, sour cherry, leather, cream caramel, cocoa powder.
Man, for such a high proof this is some good shit. Enters almost sour in a good way. Mid pallet is mellow and smooth, and the spice finishes but it’s brief. Great bourbon.
Spicy and very full bodied flavors
I miss tasting the old Elijah Craig 12yr.  This one helps miss it less now.  Packs a good punch and leaves a mouthful of flavor. Best to sip this one slowly.

Burn baby
With a lot of barrel taste
hot nose and hot throughout the tasting. still has great flavor with vanilla cherry and Carmel toward the back end. decent char flavor
batch A119, very smooth, high proof bourbon, I detected caramel notes
I had batch A119.  this is an excellent, high proof bourbon

Big body with nice color. Rich and spicy on the nose. Floral overtones. Strong bite worthy of a 130 proof liquor. With water still has a large bite but goes down smooth. Oaky and floral. A very nice neat beverage.

sweet potato aroma

earthy palate with cherry syrup at the back

oily mouthfeel

medium to long finish

B519 bottle.  Taste in line with the tasting notes. Doesn’t drink like a 60%+. Very good.

batch #8518

warm finish with great balance.  hints of grain bounce with spice and caramel

wow! this is the highest proof whiskey I've tried and was a ton of fun to enjoy. first sip is a bomb of intense flavors and moderate alcohol burn. I added a significant amount of water and enjoyed all the flavors this whiskey has to offer. excellent mouthfeel with a medium to long finish. its addictive but only after you add water

A friend shared a pour of this while I was down in AZ on business. It’s absurd! It’s like drinking bourbon shot out of a cannon - the flavors are so amped up that my brain didn’t know what to do with them. I had to put water on it and let it sit and meld back together before I could wrap my head around it.

A119

Nose: caramel, ethanol, vanilla, baking spice
Palate:oily, heat, sweet, cinnamon, vanilla
Finish: long and hot, keeps on giving, char in the middle

Maybe shouldnt have tried it neat at first. It needs ice. The flavors are robust and yummy. 
Second taste: Added a couple of cubes to start. This is one amazing bourbon. Lots of great flavors that last through the long finish.

Elijah Craig Barrel Proof (C918) is a 12 year old bourbon that is non chill filtered and clocks in at 131.4 proof! The mashbill is 78% corn, 10% rye, 12% barley. The color is a dark amber with reddish hint. The legs are thin but just cling to the glass and then run very slow. The aroma is caramel, brown sugar, and oak. On the first sip I get a slight alcohol burn but I would expect that. But by the second sip it seems to vanish. The tastes is caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, baking spice, oak, and I think I can taste dark cherries. These flavors are very bold and delicious. This one really coats your mouth with that thick oily feeling. The finish is long and the flavors just linger on and on. This is one heck of a bourbon. I look forward to getting some of the other batches soon.
Spice, cocoa, bite long finish. On rocks or with some water
First draw was pretty strong. Very good
Great taste neat or on the rocks.

brown sugar, cocoa, and leather on the nose. beautiful deep red-brown color. explosion of spicy rye and alcohol in the mouth. viscous and warm. fruit and sweet grain develop with a long finish. opens up with a little ice and develops into a really satisfying drink.
very smooth, slight hints of fruit and spice

Drank this with my adult sons in the woods at thanksgiving. Love the big bold flavor. Oak, cinnamon, vanilla, all wrapped up in a strong rye taste at 130+ proof. Perfect bourbon to bond with your sons over fire, grilled steak and surrounded by nature.

Slight alcohol nose, but also fruity. Slight burn of the tip of the tongue upon first taste. Then comes on the barrel proof spice. Strong spice, but can still taste the fruit. So surprising! Long spicy finish.
Excellent.  Honey with a hint of molasses. Long finish with oak taste.

ECBP (C918)
Nose- spice (nutmeg) and chocolate
Taste- oily mouth feel with vanilla, heavy leather, char, and spicy (almost heavy rye like)
Finish- shorter finish than expected with the proof but still long enough, with almond and more leather
Grade: 85

Batch B519: Oakey/citrusy on the nose, with plenty of ethanol. Sit for five minutes and the ethanol dissipates mostly, allowing some vanilla to join the party. Apple and pear on the palate, then a big hit of toffee and oak round out the palate. Dry, even considering the proof. Medium finish with some oak and spice, and a very dry mouthfeel on the tail end.
It's fine. Nice mouthfeel but a bit more burn on the finish than I like.
Best bourbon I have ever had. Ruins all other cask strengths for me.
Pretty strong for my taste, but good
Excellent bourbon. One of my favorites for the price.
Good taste with a little burn.
Had it at Evan Williams experience and it was delicious but I’ve had too many to give an honest full review

Heavy leather and some rye  on the nose. Thick on the tongue. Taste like cinnamon and spice pretty quickly once in the mouth with a finish of chocolate sweetness on the front of the tongue. This one has a smooth heaty burn in the back of the throat as you swallow.

Batch A119. Natural amber color, clear, and viscous. Nose is intense, with dominating rye, intermingled with vanilla, and oak. Palate is complex, with sweet, sour, and umami interplay, more rye, vanilla, cinnamon, leather, oak, anise, banana, mint, and raisins. Finish is long, dominated by rye with moderate oak coming at the back. At 67.6% ABV it does need water, and a teaspoon somewhat tames the rye, and allows more subtle notes to sound brighter. Overall, an excellent and complex bourbon that is not overloaded with oak which you may expect from a 12-year-old.

Batch A119
The nose is brown sugar, vanilla, cinnamon, and light leather.
The palate is a little sweet with vanilla and a big barrel/leathery note. And I also get a cola note. It almost seems carbonated for a second, which I’ve never gotten before from a whiskey. Maybe because it reminded me of coke? 
It has a thicker mouthfeel, but that gets lost with the dryness that happens to your tongue and cheeks. It really dries it out, like chalky almost.
All in all I like this one, but it’s the first Barrell Proof Elijah Craig. So I can’t compare to other batches.

Nose: maple syrup, butterscotch, peppercorns

Finish: medium, smooth and oily with a slight kick at the end

B519

Palate: oily, maple syrup, red fruit, orange, caramel, toffee

Loads of caramel, vanilla, and oak. This is a definite oak bomb. Thick heavy mouthfeel. A bit bitter on the finish because of this, but also has some nougat. Tastes kinda like licking the inside of a barrel. I like it but not in love. It’s complex just maybe not my flavor, at least not for the standard bottle price. 
Edit: with a touch of water more complex cherry and dusty notes come out. With more water this is becoming more my speed. Complex notes that I can’t even pick out are emerging. Rating changed from 3.0 to 3.75

LOOK OUT!!! Everything is on the table with ECBP! Clear your evening and half of your morning the next day, this is a creeper! At the price point and proof, there is no better bourbon as balanced, smooth and dangerously delicious. No contest, period!
Let this one air out. Sip it slow and as time passes you adjust and the whiskey opens up. The last drink is its best and it’s a good one.
For a barrel strength bourbon, I prefer Stagg Jr, all day. More complexity. This was hot and had some chocolate and cherry, but Stagg Jr has more captivating flavors and smoother finish.
I really like this, but it is just a little too strong to be a everyday drinker for me

I’ve been an EC fan for several years but never had the BP version until now. A little floral but more of a roasted nut like a cashew on the nose. Plenty of varnish on the taste and surprisingly goes down somewhat smooth with some good burn.
Very full bodied. Really thick and complex and oily. Super hot. 135 proof.
Tons of caramel and vanilla for me, and a delicious long finish

It smells hot but not super hot. There’s cherry, oak and brown sugar on the nose. But of caramel on the palate, with a lot of pepper and cinnamon. It’s super hot on the palate but shockingly smooth going down. Very similar to stagg jr.
Camping in sequoia. Very drinkable. No aftertaste.
Took me a while but I finally got a bottle from batch B519. Oily creamy mouthfeel and packed with flavor. It is super smooth for the proof but still get that nice Kentucky hug!

Ok to cleanse as is, but MUST ADD WATER 
Nose - excellent, Heathbar, toasted cereal maybe. 
Palate - rich, long finish, complex sweet front and finish.
Had it at Mack and Donna for Thanksgiving 2020. Very sweet. Smooth
Sweet, and surprisingly smooth for 61.1% alcohol.

Maraschino cherries and brown sugar on the nose.

Brown sugar, cocoa, vanilla, dry oak.

A splash of water makes the brown sugar on the nose all the more robust.  Caramel notes.

The palate opens up with rich caramel and more vanilla.

This is a review of Elijah Craig Barrel Proof batch B519. These notes are taken from several tastings over the past three months. This is one of (if not The) best bourbons I have ever had.

ECBP is a 12 year age stated bourbon from Heaven Hill. This batch is bottled at 61.1% ABV. It pours a gorgeous dark amber and leaves a thick oily coating and long slow legs in the glass. 

The nose has dark molasses, brown sugar, chocolate cherries, caramel, vanilla. A veritable explosion of dark sweetness. Very little alcohol considering the ABV. Water has very little effect on the nose. 

In the mouth there’s more of the same plus dark chocolate and burnt sugar. Mouthwatering. A sweet bomb. Heat on the back end but not overpowering. Water makes it richer, more buttery. Just fantastic. 

The long finish has notes of chocolate covered cherries, oak char, tobacco, leather, and black pepper. Water brings out more baking spices. Either way you get a big Kentucky hug. 

Like I said, this is one of, if not the, best bourbons I’ve had. I really can’t find anything wrong with it. The only one that comes close to this is Bookers. The only Bookers batch I’ve had had an odd note of green oak, so this definitely has the edge. On top of that this bottle was a mere $55 online which makes it an absolute steal. I’m giving this 4.5 plus an extra quarter point for value. 4.75/5. Cheers!

Nose:  Big citrus and cherry on the front end followed by an ethanol bite and a bit of sharp minty/herbal note.  There's some sort of spicy, yet cooling herbs and a real amount of oak.  Thick, dark molasses and caramel on the nose now, with an almost burnt sugar and oak twist at the end.  Brown sugar syrup hides the herbs after it sits for a bit.

Palate:  Hot and mouthcoating.  Wow, that is an explosion of hot, spicy, corn!  There is no hiding that 61.1%abv, which I don't know if I particularly like here.  Immediately after that heat, there's a fleeting (very fleeting) grapefruit and lime note that I'm really surprised by, like this bitter/sour/floral type of thing that is hard to describe.   There so much cinnamon and spice packed in here that the cherry and vanilla are hidden a bit, but still there.  Caramel and corn sweetness round out that hot start.

Finish:  Medium length and mouthwatering.  That initial spice and heat burst doesn't last long.  The next wave is the sweeter fruit and vanilla, but the subtle corn and caramel lasts for some time.  Every once in a while that herbal/oaky note comes back for a visit.

water doesn't really do great things for the nose on this, it pretty much turns into a citrus-scented cleaning solvent.  On the tongue, however, it becomes this thick, velvety syrup that feels like you can actually chew on it!  Much less heat and so much more oak and spice now, that almost too-sweet caramel turns into a really nice almost-burnt toffee that goes really well with all that barrel char.  That little bit of water makes this last and last!  It's kind of like repeatedly liking the inside of a charred barrel that's been coated in caramel.  Wow, this is so much better with water.

Conclusion:  I'm really not blown away with this stuff straight from the bottle, in fact, I don't think I'd ever order a glass even for a great price.  It's just too hot, and not in a good way either.  I've had some great barrel proofs that are nice and warming with enough strong flavors to break through that ethanol.  This, however, is just hot for the sake of being hot.  After adding a pretty generous amount of water this becomes something I'd order everyday!  Though the nose is not something to call home about, the smokey toffee that shines through is the perfect thing for a cold night!
Tasted again side by side with Russell 10 year. Elijah Craig was way better.
Alcoholic taste, thin on tongue. This has got a kick bourbon
Nose is strong! Struggling to find notes. Definite licorice notes in the mouth. Sweet. Buttery. Warm, spicy finish and anise/oak flavor linger.
Solid bourbon with different tastes on every sip
A lot of heat on this bad boy
Sweet, bold flavors and spice. Typical cask strength.
B518. Coming back to this after a year of air in the bottle. Intense cinnamon front and center with dark grapes and berries close behind. Flavor bomb!
Great bourbon, smooth, caramel notes are very noticeable and very balanced.
A very good bourbon. Top 10 but not top 5

This was an excellent bourbon.

Strong hot chili pepper up front due to the high proof. Lots of oak spice as well. Once my palate adjusted to the proof I found bitter chocolate, juicy cherry, & rich caramel. Still plenty of oak spicy throughout the dram.

C917. Nose is spicy, ethanol heavy, with maybe some sugary notes. Palate is an ethanol explosion with a backdrop of brown sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg, and then some bitter oak on a medium+ to long finish. Needs water to balance it out but that bitter oak never really leaves. Not my favorite.

Holy heat Batman!  This one burns, didn’t even open up much with a couple drops of h2o.  Next pour of this will be on the rocks.

*update*. Tried in the rocks, improved the shock and burn.  Think may try in a mixer as well which I typically don’t...however it’s still a decent sipper
First BP, insane smooth for proof - 12 professional years of maturing though.  W Uncle Michael

Batch C918 65.7%
Pretty hot neat, good flavor, but a bit much. Sharper nose, a little spicy, a little floral, less sweet. Overall good.

Nose - carmel. Syrup. Peanuts. Vanilla. Bury nosed in carmel corn. Cherry bitters

Taste - sweet homemade caramels. Little hints of cocoa. Vanilla. Roasted peanuts lots of barrel char

Finish -long long finish  heat. Oaky nuttiness. Followed by camrel
Sweet corn and oak on the nose. Palate is hot but with spice not alcohol. Cinnamon, pepper.... finish is long corn, dark fruit and oak. Reminds me of a less sweet heavier version of eh Taylor.

Deep strong wood aroma, smells like a barrel proof whiskey. Subtle sweetness underneath though, maybe cherry. Reminds me of knob Creek. Super aggressive creamy flavor, high alcohol burn, but more sweet than wood at the start. Beautiful complexity that flows well. Oak definitely dominates through the tail. A little water let's the sweetness shine through.

Yummy! This was fun to drink. Beyond the nose, the taste started off with charred barrel and some anise flavors. A dash of water opened it up to cinnamon, dark caramels, and a little pepper. Another dash brought out some milk chocolate covered cherries. Then some more and it was tasting like the usual small batch EC. Fun stuff. Fun when wet.

Hmm I'm not having a good run with bourbons lately. Not because they are bad but they are just not a profile I like. Very sickly sweet cherry, liquorice etc. I can see how people would rate this highly as it's a quality dram but you could say that about a good kombucha or such like... great quality wholesome drink but urgh zero balance just over powering sweet simplicity. 2 for flavour 4.5 for quality call it 3.5 even

12/19/19

Batch: B519 
ABV: 61.1%

Nose: baking spice and vanilla

Palate: spicy cinnamon and rye with hint of chocolate 

Finish: long with smooth heat and great baking and rye spice 

So smooth for proof and must have on top shelf
Lots of heat, but has a great spicy background that finishes with herbal notes

On the nose there is baking spices and rye, very full. On the palate there is some heat but it does not overpower you. Lots of barrel, baking spices and caramel. The finish is medium to long and is very smooth. This is a fantastic bourbon and a must have!

New to rating whiskey so bear with me. Spicy and sweet. Vanilla & tobacco seem to dominate. Mouthfeel is medium-thick. Overall, don’t know how much I like barrel proof. The flavors are nice but the alcohol has a tough bite
Added a little splash of water.  Brown sugar, oak and honey. Slight floral note. Oily and rich.
Good barrel strength. Little on the hot side with a bit of after burn.

Nose - Very strong ethanol upfront that develops into a delicious typical bourbon smell. Nice wood notes that hide a faint sweetness. 
Palate - Solid oak and char notes that leave a great mouthfeel. Very rich buttery notes. Hides the sweet behind the spice. 
Finish - Salty and spicy finish that lingers in the back of the throat. Lingers a bit but not a long finish. 

Water cuts most of the spice and brings out the slight sweetness for a very

Batch C918. It's hot,  but under that is rich brown sugar, vanilla, and a hint of caramel in the nose. The flavor matches although I don't get the caramel as much and there is maybe a hint of pepper in the upper palate mixed in with the alcohol heat that lingers there. It is a wonderful bourbon.

Burn sweet burn! 
Once the initial shock goes away the sweetness comes through and a nice smooth finish
I’m drinking the C917 at 65.5%. Wow! What a nose! Cinnamon, vanilla, oak and rye. Wallop on the tongue. Lots of spice but some sweetness as well. Long finish. Beautiful
Spicy, nicely hot, well rounded bourbon with a great finish. This is has become my “go to” while I try and figure out the over priced bourbon market. I love this bourbon.
B519 release. Very smooth for 122 proof. Very full and smooth. Hints of roasted peanuts on the nose along with vanilla and caramel. Taste is long and sweet.
Lots of rye so it has a bite, but also chocolate, vanilla and spices. Very tasty.

There are 3 batches released three times (January, May, September) a year on this Barrel Proof one, which is unfiltered and no water added either.....A, B, and C. Check reviews on Distiller app to compare ratings.
The heat is amazing. Really taste and smell the barrel.
Very smooth and warm. Nice mouthfeel. Deep toffee flavor and stays nicely on the palette. Little spice at the end too.

C919 Starts with a sweet caramel and turns into brown sugar. Then turns to oak barrel heat.  The high proof is felt in the deep throat as a steady burn in the long finish.  It’s a little oily and goes down as smooth as a 138 proof whiskey could go down.

B519 Nose is strong alcohol and brown sugar pallet is more brown sugar plenty of rye burn comes in strong and then mellows out into a ky hug. Finish is plenty of low key spice and lingers for a while.
Definitely got the cinnamon, surprising. I don’t get as strong of a nose as the tasting notes. This is really good.

This particular bottle is from batch B518 and comes in at 133.4 proof. Being uncut and unfiltered it is quite dark in the glass.

Nose: The nose is dominated by campfire and brown sugar. Think the smell of charred logs. The alcohol is also very present but a couple drops of water do a good job of taming it.

Palate: Very rich. Buttery biscuits at first then molasses comes next. The high alcohol content makes the flavors incredibly intense, almost eye watering.

Finish: Starts with barrel char and smoke that eventual fades to black tea. Goes on for a bit aided by the proof. The addition of water does shorten the finish slightly.

At under $100 this is a very good value. The addition of water helped the nose but I don’t think it helped the palate or the finish so my preferred method has been to start neat and then add a couple of drops around halfway through so I get the best of both worlds. Will certainly be enjoying every drop of this while it lasts.

Cheers!

Heaven hills best offering to date but not for the beginner and not for the faint of heart. I recommend trying neat then adding a few drops of water to really pull the flavors out of here. BIG and BOLD should be this bourbons nickname as it will take you back a step when nosing or tasting. Verdict: Very very good stuff but beware the high proof and explosive nose and palate.

Batch A119, 67.6% abv

The abv is so high that you can feel the whiskey evaporating off your tongue when you sip it, very strange sensation. The flavors are dark, rich, and intense. Turns out that’s not entirely a good thing by itself. Really needs something bright in there to provide balance and keep it interesting. But if you want to be overwhelmed by caramel, vanilla, leather, etc. then it’s worth a shot.

B918- Honey nose

(Tasted at Bourbon Bastards, 1/23/20)
Better as old fashion or in cocktail as opposed to neat
Needs to be cut with mixer
Will knock your dick in the dirt. Need to mix or dilute.
Best ever. Smooth. Big burn. Vanilla
Heavy spice, add water, sipping whiskey
Sweet, powerful nose .. great mouth feel .. long finish
Amazingly smooth considering its 122 proof. Spicy and rich up front m. You only need a couple of these. Definitely one to keep in the collection (it doesn’t last long).

Accidentally deleted my entry. Don’t remember exactly what I wrote, but it was extremely hot and I couldn’t get far past that. Took my breath away. Wood spice, cherry and corn sweetness are what I remember.
The C batch for 2019 is so good. It won me over in a blind test with B batch and some other stiff barrel proof competition. High Proof, but surprisingly smooth and little heat
It is surprisingly smooth given high proof. A very fine bourbon
Phenomenal flavors. Stunning color too. Just wow.
Super barrel forward almost too harsh 3.5. Added a cube then was able to taste cinnamon and vanilla much better flavor with a small cube. 3.8ish

In my opinion, this bourbon is superior to Blanton Single Barrel. As a person generally off-put by heavy spice, this bourbon only has enough to balance out the deliciously creamy and sweet flavors. If it is too strong, try a few drops of water but not too much. As of the collection I've gathered over 2 years now, this is easily the BEST, most incredibly well balanced, full bodied and rich bourbon I have ever had. Makes me want to buy every bottle I can find for those down times between releases, haha. My batch is C419

Batch C919. Took a few glasses to figure it out, but finally added a few drops of water. It makes a huge difference - in a good way. Now I taste the vanilla, cinnamon, and oak. The nose is also much better after a couple drops of water. I get lots of vanilla and something fruity, but can't quite figure out what. I really enjoy this bourbon.
Spicy but super smooth and full of barrel  notes and flavor. Definitely hot and will give you the old Kentucky hug, but it’s worth it!!
Sweet and spicy with subtle oaky-nuttiness. Need to love a strong Kentucky hug.
lingering, deeply potent, spicy-oak and vanilla goodness at a super value and not impossible to find

Elijah Craig Barrel Proof C919 - 4.5/5

• Palate - Heat, oily, rich

For 60 dollars this may be the best spicy boy around.

향 : 고도수로 잠겨진 버번, 태운오크의 달콤함, 브라운슈가, 높은 도수의 알콜, 옅은 페퍼민트
맛 : 강력한 흑설탕 후 페퍼민트, 버번 파이팅 넘치는 스파이시, 잠시 머금자 입안의 수분을 흡수하는 높은 도수, 
피니쉬 : 깔끔한 우디함, 목에서 열감

워터드롭 후
훨씬 풀리고 부드러운 흑설탕&페퍼민트

Sticks to the glass and lingers after a quick swirl. The color is of orange marmalade. On the nose there is oak, caramel and cedar. After sipping I get werthers candies, spice and oak. A touch of cinnamon on the finish, accentuated with the more drops of water I add. It is sweet and sticky. The aftertaste is squelched by the alcohol and tannins. 

This pour gets points for getting me into more barrel proof bourbons. But it isn’t as complex or balanced as I once thought. Nevertheless, a good whiskey.
A119: "Nose and initial taste hit hard. Let sit and some ice, flavors open up. Nice balance. Recommend for the right price”

Batch A120. Spicy alcohol and pepper, mellows to baking spice and apple and a vanilla sweetness. Long oily finish that has the taste of cinnamon

Packs a spicy punch! Great oaky notes.

Deep Amber in Color, nose of Cherry and charred oak. Slight vanilla and lots of nutty notes, more pecan.  Flavor is also nutty, with toasted or dark caramel. Peppery long finish. Certainly warming. Lots of tannins. After a few drops of water a floral Aroma found and more nut notes in flavor. More prickly with water. (posted this to specific batch as well) B518
Man this batch was near perfection. So much depth and flavor that lingers long!
Phenomenal. Batch B520. Youd never know it was 127.2 proof. Picking up another bottle before this batch is gone.
Great nose.  Strong taste without much heat.  Chocolate notes start and finish
Full bodied with a deep flavor that hits the entire mouth. This is how a good bourbon should taste
C919. Tons of flavor. Really sweet. Bold brown sugar. Barrel char. Cherry.
Warms up the mouth instantly. Salivation explosion. Flavor morph. Mapley, sweet, smoky.
So unique. Such a strong nose...hard to pick out any notes. Big, oaky with hints of vanilla and caramel. A lot of heat but still very satisfying. One of the most unique bourbons so far! (Thanks Dan!)

Nose: walnut, vanilla, wood, dark cherries almost plum
Palate: chocolate, green apple, cinnamon, nutmeg
Finish: long, warm, creamy finish

I love EC, but this one hits just a little too hard for me. To its credit I am more of a scotch guy but there lacks a depth in flavor for this one for me at such a high proof. 
It has a brilliant nose, so much of the notes that you get off standard EC but with the heat turned up a few notches. You get a good introduction to a “this is high proof bourbon” statement.

The flavors get lost in the proofing after that. I get a taste that is slightly reminiscent of bile in my mouth after I’ve swallowed.  Now it is brought into manageable play with a couple ice cubes but I prefer my drams neat most times.

Neat: Leather with hint of vanilla; hot - warms mouth immediately and will feel it in your chest for awhile
Ice: More vanilla; some cinnamon; much sweeter and smoother

One of my favorite high proofs so far
Full texture with just the right amount of sweet. Finishes with a hint of smokiness.
After my taste buds were burned off, great flavors of oak, butterscotch and spice, then more oak...careful, this one is dangerous but, in a good way!

C918 131.4 proof, for such high proof it needs ice, but opens up nice.

You're wondering who I am-machine or mannequin. With parts made in Japan, I am the modern whiskey man. 

Pro tip: Secret secret, I’ve got a secret.
